X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=_B0xK5Q6OnRciEnU9AZdO-i2kM59_FIPlKvu7vu0Ijrf2AMcDWVg

Peter, I'll try to answer your questions as best I can, though some of
the =
conceptual issues are pretty difficult to answer concretely.

One thing I w=
ant to note is that I do not believe that adding and
subtracting is "more" =
important than composing functions.  However, it
is indeed important, and I=
 emphasized it because when thinking about
CPPNs it has been common to focu=
s on the compositional aspect.  The
adding and subtracting can be thought o=
f as a way of combining shapes.
 For example, a circle and a square can com=
bine to create a circle
with a square hole (i.e. circle minus square).  In =
this way, you can
get very complex shapes easily that conform in ways that =
may not look
like the original activation functions from which they derive.=


However, composition is clearly still critical because these "cutout"
sha=
pes are the outputs of individual nodes that then become coordinate
frames =
for even higher functions.  In this way, composition is still
going on, but=
 it involves intermediate steps that may be difficult to
visualize.

The ut=
ility I spoke about simply allows you to visualize all the
intermediate ste=
ps.  It's fairly simple to implement.  Just think of
any hidden node in the=
 CPPN as being the output and then just draw a
picture corresponding to wha=
t *that* node's activation is at any given
(x,y).  In this way, every hidde=
n node in the network has an internal
"picture" that we can easily see if w=
e simply render it.  You can then
create visualizations that attempt to sho=
w the order of the creation
of the ultimate pattern, picture by picture, fr=
om bottom to top (of
course, it is only a partial order unless the network =
is a perfect
chain).   

If you wanted to be really creative, you could cre=
ate a big virtual
window with scroll bars in which each node is shown with =
its internal
picture rendered entirely inside it.  Then the user could just=

navigate up the network at leisure and see how one thing leads to
another.=
  This kind of visualization is analogous to watching
embryonic "developmen=
t" from start to finish.

When you ask if we can analyze this in a determin=
istic way without
using evolution, could you provide more detail on that qu=
estion?  As I
am thinking of it, this type of analysis is performed on the =
product
of evolution, i.e. on a particular genome, so I am not sure what yo=
u
mean by "without" evolution.  If you mean that you'd like a kind of
theor=
etical explanation of the way the space of possible patterns is
encoded, I =
think it's an interesting question, but I don't have a good
answer other th=
an intuitive explanations such as the one above.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogro=
ups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@...>
wrote:

ideness on how to implement that myself and use it?

he most is the additions and subtractions of the

e hidden nodes? I assume you mean the "output 
> =3D function( sum(i1 * w1 =
+ i2 * w2 + ... + in * wn + bias) )". Then 
> actually the weights of the c=
onnections inputting into the node are 
> really more important than the pr=
eceeeding functions above it. Of 
> course, if a weight is close to zero th=
en it has almost no influence 
> to the node. In a stream of conciosness I =
am continuing with some

o the same node, it 
> is combining them or in other words, adding/subtract=
ing them, right. 
> Did you see any difference with lower "add-link" mutati=
on rates? 
> Where more nodes are being added with only one input and one o=
utput 
> link? 
> I know what the weights themselves mean, they are scalars=
 of the

on (a 
> coordinate frame) is laid on top of another. But how do you explai=
n

> tog=
ether? Are we able to actually analyze that in a deterministic way

ut using evolution to see stuff? See, I know this is possible,

looking for the easy and clean way, you know.. 
> 
> Peter
